abstract.text: An abstract class that models timed audiovisual media.
An abstract class that models timed audiovisual media.
An asset subclass used to initialize an asset from a local or remote URL.
A protocol you use to load an asset’s or asset track’s media and metadata without blocking the calling thread.
Creates a new asset object that models the media at the specified URL.
A time value that indicates the asset’s duration.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the asset provides precise duration and timing.
The asset’s preferred playback rate.
The asset’s preferred audio volume.
The preferred transform to apply to the asset’s visual content during presentation or processing.
A time value that indicates how closely playback follows the latest live stream content.
The encoded or authored size of the visual portion of the asset.
A Boolean value that indicates whether this asset has playable content.
A Boolean value that indicates whether you can export this asset using an export session.
A Boolean value that indicates whether you can extract the asset’s media data using an asset reader.
A Boolean value that indicates whether you can use the asset as a segment of a composition track.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the asset has protected content.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the asset is compatible with AirPlay Video.
A Boolean value that indicates whether you can write the asset to the Saved Photos album.
The media tracks this asset contains.
Returns the track associated with the specified track identifier.
Returns an array of asset tracks matching the specified media type.
Returns an array of asset tracks matching the specified media characteristic.
Returns an ID that’s unused by any of the tracks in the asset.
The track groups this asset contains.
A group of related tracks in an asset.
An array of metadata items for all metadata identifiers for which a value is available.
An array of metadata items for each common metadata key for which a value is available.
The metadata formats this asset contains.
Returns an array of metadata items found in the container with the specified format.
A metadata item that indicates the asset’s creation date.
The lyrics of the asset in a language suitable for the current locale.
The locales of the asset’s chapter metadata.
Returns an array of chapters with a given title locale and containing the specified keys.
Returns an array of chapters whose locale best matches the list of preferred languages.
The array of available media selections for this asset.
The default media selections for this asset’s media selection groups.
An array of media characteristics for which a media selection option is available.
Returns a media selection group that contains one or more options with the specified media characteristic.
The asset’s reference restrictions.
Restrictions to use when resolving references to external media data.
A Boolean value that indicates whether you can extend the asset by fragments.
A Boolean value that indicates whether at least one movie fragment extends the asset.
The total duration of fragments that currently exist, or may exist in the future.
Cancels all pending requests to asynchronously load property values.
The display criteria that define the optimal TV display mode for the asset.
An object that contains properties defining the display criteria for a media asset.
Understand how you use assets as the building blocks for various media use cases.
An object that provides the track-level interface to inspect an asset’s media tracks.
Query the suitability properties to determine whether you can perform the indicated operation, even if only under a specific set of conditions.

inlineContent.text: defines the collective properties of the tracks that comprise the asset. You create an
by initializing it with a local or remote URL pointing to a media resource, as shown in the following example:

code:
let url: URL = // Local or Remote Asset URL
let asset = AVAsset(url: url)

inlineContent.text: is an abstract class, so when you create an asset as shown in the example, you’re actually creating an instance of one of its concrete subclasses called
. In many cases this is a suitable way of creating an asset, but you can also directly instantiate an
when you need more fine-grained control over its initialization. The initializer for

accepts an options dictionary, with which you tailor the asset’s initialization to your particular use case. For instance, if you’re creating an asset for an HLS stream, you may want to prevent it from retrieving its media when a user is connected to a cellular network. You can do this as shown in the following example:
You can also instantiate an asset using other concrete subclasses that extend the basic model for audiovisual media in useful ways, as

does for temporal editing.Because of the nature of timed audiovisual media, upon successful initialization of an asset, some or all of the values for its keys may not be immediately available. The value of any key can be requested at any time, and the asset always returns its value synchronously, although it may have to block the calling thread to do so. To avoid blocking, you can register your interest in particular keys and be notified when their values become available. For further details, see
with it, use the player item to set up its presentation state (such as whether only a limited time range of the asset should be played), and provide the player item to an
object according to whether the item is to be played by itself or with a collection of other items.You can insert
object to assemble audiovisual constructs from one or more source assets.
to handle streaming protocols or file formats that the framework doesn’t support.
